author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Judge urged to send former Bloomberg official to prison
text:
Jesse Ward/Jesse Ward for New York Daily Ne Wendell Walters faces up to 17 years in prison. He will be sentenced Wednesday. The city's Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development is urging a Brooklyn judge to send a former top official of the agency to prison for pocketing $2.5 million in bribes and kickbacks from developers — despite his cooperation with the feds.
Wendell Walters, the highest ranking official in the Bloomberg administration to be arrested on corruption charges, is facing up to 17 years in prison when he is sentenced Wednesday by Federal Judge Nina Gershon.
“He has breached, in the worst possible way, his duty to his co-workers, to his fellow New Yorkers, and to society itself. He has caused lasting damage to the reputation of an agency that has done great work to revitalize this city and to aid its most vulnerable citizens,” HPD Commissioner Vicki Breen wrote the judge. “We should show zero tolerance for such misdeeds.”
Federal prosecutors have also written the judge, suggesting Walters, who pleaded guilty in 2012, get less than the low end of the sentencing guidelines recommendation of 14 years in prison because of his cooperation against other defendants.
Walters, who blames his stunning downfall on chasing the dream of owning a valuable townhouse on Strivers Row in Harlem, is seeking a sentence of community service.
